headline.main: WHEN FAT WAS IN FASHION; Abundant flesh was a thing of beauty to Peter Paul Rubens, whose 400th birthday is being celebrated this year. And Rubens was not alone, for until the 20th century, fatness was a sign of health and wealth. Today there may be a slim chance for a revival of plump pulchritude.

docs.abstract: article on obesity and changing concepts of beauty throughout the centuries cites paintings of Peter Paul Reubens; illus
docs.lead_paragraph: Somewhere in the first 15 minutes of "North by Northwest," Cary Grant pats his stomach, frowns, and tells his secretary to make a note: "Think thin!" Everybody in the audience laughs in instant sympathy--we are all patting our stomachs and thinking thin as hard as we can. One glance at the art of Rubens, however, shows that this...
